title: About
text: It contains lectures and exercises on Ancient DNA data analysis from a workshop conducted at the University of Siegen, in collaboration with the University of Bonn, on September 6-7, 2022.

title: Ancient DNA Data Analysis - Workshop Uni Siegen 2022
text: Welcome to the Website for the “Ancient DNA Data Analysis” workshop.

title: Ancient DNA Data Analysis - Workshop Uni Siegen 2022
text: Learning objectives

title: Ancient DNA Data Analysis - Workshop Uni Siegen 2022
text:
RStudio-Cloud
Our interactive exercises are done in RStudio-Cloud.
In order to join our “classroom” workspace, you need to follow this link. Then follow these steps:

Click on “Sign up” to create a free account, or, if you already have an account, simply log in
In the workshop space, you should now see “Join Space?” -> Click “YES”
In the top menu, click on “Projects”
You should see a project named “Ancient_DNA_Workshop_Sept_2022”. Click on “Start” right next to it.
You should now see something like this:

title: Ancient DNA Data Analysis - Workshop Uni Siegen 2022

title: Part 1 - From bones to sequences
text:
What is Archaeogenetics?

Genetic Analysis of prehistoric organic remains
Examples: bones, teeth, dental calculus, antler, hair, seed, wood, pollen, soil, coprolites

title: Part 1 - From bones to sequences
text:
Why archaeogenetics?

Why are we doing this? Why are prehistoric genetic data important?
Because genetic variability in the past can not be derived unambiguously from genetic variability in the presence.







Images by Wolfgang Haak

title: Part 1 - From bones to sequences
text:
Sources of ancient DNA




Human DNA (Mitochondrial DNA, Nuclear DNA)




Pathogen DNA (Bacteria, Viruses, Protists)




Environmental DNA (Plants, Funghi, Bacteria, Viruses, Animals)

title: Part 1 - From bones to sequences
section: What happens in an ancient DNA laboratory?
text: What happens in an ancient DNA laboratory?

title: Part 1 - From bones to sequences
text:
From evolutionary to family history







Novembre and Ramachandran 2011, Annu. Rev. Genomics Hum. Genet. 2011.

title: Part 1 - From bones to sequences
text:
DNA degradation



Ancient DNA is short (50-100 bp)
Ancient DNA has chemically changed after death (C->U->T changes at the ends)
Ancient DNA is partly single-stranded (strand breaks)









Images: Stoneking and Krause 2011, Nat Rev Gen; Wolfgang Haak

title: Part 1 - From bones to sequences
text:
Sequencing Data
This is how sequencing reads look like on a computer:

samtools view data/Sample.bam | cut -f10 | head

CGCCCTATTAACCACTCACGGGAGCTCTCCATGCATTTA
CCTATTAACCACTCACGGGAGCTCTCCATGCATTTGGTATT
TATTAACCACTCACGGGAGCTCTCCATGCATTTGGTATTTTCGTCTGGGGAGTATGCACGCGATAGCATTGCGAGA
TATTAACCACTCACGGGAGCTCTCCATACATTTGGTATTTTCGTCTGGGGGGTATGCACGCGATAGCATTGCGAGA
TCACGGGAGCTCTCCATGCATTTGGTATTTTCGTCTGGGGGGTATGCACGCGATAGCATTGCGAGACGCTGAAGCC
TCACGGGAGCTCTCCATGCATTTGGTATTTTCGTCTGGGGGGTATGCACGCGATAGCATTGCGAGACGCTGAAGCC
GAGCTTTTCATGTATTTGGTATTTTCGTCTGGGGGGTATGCACGCGATAGCATTGCGAGATGTTGGA
TCATGCATTTGGTATTTTCGTCTGGGGGGTATGCACGCGATAGCATTGCGAGACGCT
ATTTGGTATTTTTGTTTGGGGGGTATGCACGCGATAGCATTGCGAG
CATCTGGGGGGTATGCACACGATAGCATTGCGAGACGCTGGAA



Problem: Sequencing reads are short, the human genome is long.







Note


Note that the samtools view command is used here and introduced later.









Tip


If you’re familiar with the command line, you can try out the command (samtools view ...) yourself. The data is available from this repository.

title: Part 1 - From bones to sequences
text:
Solution: Alignments

Every short fragment gets mapped onto the human genome
Fast mapping algorithms use sophisticated indexing of the human genome to quickly find a matching position



A typical way to visualise such alignments is shown here:


1         11        21        31        41        51        61        71        
GATCACAGGTCTATCACCCTATTAACCACTCACGGGAGCTCTCCATGCATTTGGTATTTTCGTCTGGGGGGTATGCACGC
              .G................................................................
              ,g,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,a       ,a,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,a,
                 ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,   ,,,,,,,a,a,,,,,,,,,
                   ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,a,,,,,,,,,,
                   ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,a,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,
                             ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,
                             ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,
                                   .....T.T....T................................
                                          T.....................................
                                                ............T..T................
                                                                        ,,,,,,,,
                                                                         ,,,,,,,
                                                                           .....




Or without the reference genome:


1         11        21        31        41        51        61        71        
NNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNN
              CGCCCTATTAACCACTCACGGGAGCTYTYCATRYATTTRGTATTTTYRTYTGGGRRRTATGCACRC
              cgccctattaaccactcacgggagctctccatgcattta       catctggggggtatgcacac
                 cctattaaccactcacgggagctctccatgcatttggtatt   gtctgggagatatgcacgc
                   tattaaccactcacgggagctctccatgcatttggtattttcgtctggggagtatgcacgc
                   tattaaccactcacgggagctctccatacatttggtattttcgtctggggggtatgcacgc
                             tcacgggagctctccatgcatttggtattttcgtctggggggtatgcacgc
                             tcacgggagctctccatgcatttggtattttcgtctggggggtatgcacgc
                                   GAGCTTTTCATGTATTTGGTATTTTCGTCTGGGGGGTATGCACGC
                                          TCATGCATTTGGTATTTTCGTCTGGGGGGTATGCACGC
                                                ATTTGGTATTTTTGTTTGGGGGGTATGCACGC
                                                                        atgcacgc
                                                                         tgcacgc
                                                                           CACGC






Top line: Reference genome
Second line: Consensus sequence
Other lines: fragments

title: Part 1 - From bones to sequences
text:
RStudio Cloud

RStudio is an open source and free platform for data science
RStudio-Cloud is a browser-based version

title: Part 1 - From bones to sequences
text:
Our Turn

Go to our workshop’s website: XXX
Click on the access link to join our workshop space on RStudio Cloud
Click on “Sign up” to create a free account, or, if you already have an account, simply log in
In the workshop space, you should now see “Join Space?” -> Click “YES”
In the top menu, click on “Projects”
You should see a project named “Ancient_DNA_Workshop_Sept_2022”. Click on “Start” right next to it.

title: Part 1 - From bones to sequences
text:
Your Turn
Open a terminal (such as the one included in RStudio or RStudio Cloud), and try out samtools tview yourself by going to the terminal, below, and running samtools tview data/Sample.bam or samtools tview data/Sample.bam --reference data/HG19_MT.fasta. Use your cursors to move left and right, space or Ctrl-L to make bigger jumps to the right, or Ctrl-H for bigger jumps to the left. Type ? to get a quick help, and q to quit.

title: Part 1 - From bones to sequences
text:
Your Turn (Exercise 1.1)

Make sure you have access to our RStudio project, as described on the workshop webpage (https://stschiff.github.io/Ancient_DNA_Workshop_Sept_2022/)
Open the file exercise_1_1_alignment.txt under presentations.
Edit the file to visually align the sequencing Reads to the given Reference genome:
Reference_Genome: AACACTTGGTCACTGGGGTTTACACTGGTACACTGGACTACCCTGGGTACACTGACTACGACTACGACTACGTTTACCCCAATTT
Sequencing_Reads:
GTTTACACTGGTGCACTGGACTACCCTG ACACTGGTGCACTGGACTACCCTGGGTACACTGACTAC TGGTGCACTGGACTACCCTGGGTACACT GACTACCCTGGGTACACTGACTACGA GGTACACTGACTACGACTACGACTACGTT







Tip


There may be single basepair mismatches. Find them!

title: Part 1 - From bones to sequences
text:
Your Turn (Exercise 1.2)

Click into the terminal in RStudio
Change into the presentations directory by typing cd presentations, followed by <Enter>
Run samtools tview data/Sample.bam
Also try samtools tview data/Sample.bam --reference data/HG19_MT.fasta







Tip



Use your cursors to move left and right
Use space or Ctrl-L to make bigger jumps to the right
Use or Ctrl-H for bigger jumps to the left.
Type ? to get a quick help
Type q to quit.

title: Part 1 - From bones to sequences
text:
Solution 1.1
                        Mismatch A -> G               Mismatch G->C
                             |                             |
                             |                             |
                             V                             V
AACACTTGGTCACTGGGGTTTACACTGGTACACTGGACTACCCTGGGTACACTGACTACGACTACGACTACGTTTACCCCAATTT
                 GTTTACACTGGTGCACTGGACTACCCTG
                     ACACTGGTGCACTGGACTACCCTGGGTACACTGACTAC
                         TGGTGCACTGGACTACCCTGGGTACACT
                                   GACTACCCTGGGTACACTGACTACCA
                                             GGTACACTGACTACCACTACGACTACGTT
